text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Six people are killed and more than 20 are injured as hundreds of people leave Mombasa for their up-country homes after violence spreads north of Mombasa.
- Finance Minister Musalia Mudavadi says the government will renew talks with the International Monetary Fund to sort out differences that led to it halting an aid package to Kenya.
- Four people are killed in a explosion in a discotheque in Murang'a during a a wedding party.
- Four more people are killed overnight on Saturday as violence that erupted south of Mombasa spreads to the north coast.
- Roman Catholic bishops call for an indefinite suspension of the general election until the dialogue on constitutional reform is complete.
- Many tourists overseas are cancelling their bookings for holidays in Kenya in the wake of violence at the coast.
- Suspects arrested in connection with the violence on the coast to appear in a Mombasa court on Monday.
- A group calling itself Opposition United Rebels claims responsibility for the current violence in Mombasa.
- President Daniel arap Moi links the violence in Mombasa to tribalism incited by opposition leaders with selfish interests.
- Regional foreign ministers meeting in Kampala on the Burundi sanctions over the weekend criticse Kenya for reopening air links with Bujumbura and demanded the links be cut.
- The International Monetary Fund is unlikely to reach a deal with Kenya's finance minister unless he is given a fresh mandate by the government.
- Tanzania completes the installation of cargo and passenger screening equipment at Kilimanjaro and Dar es Salaam airports to improve airport security and passenger safety. ($1=69.8 Kenyan shillings)
